questions.explanation: The clinical scenario and the image showing hyperpigmentation of palmar creases and oralmucosa are suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency. It presents with low aldosterone, highrenin, and high ACTH levels.In primary adrenal insufficiency, lack of aldosterone production results in compensatory rise inACTH and renin levels. The high ACTH results in hyperpigmentation. The most common causesare autoimmune in developed countries and tuberculosis in developing countries.In secondary adrenal insufficiency, there is pituitary dysfunction leading to low ACTH levels.Renin and aldosterone levels are normal, as they function independently of ACTH.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of primary hyperaldosteronism?
questions.explanation: Bilateral nodular hyperplasia of the adrenal glands is the most common cause of primaryhyperaldosteronism.Adrenal adenoma is the second most common cause. It is usually solitary, but multiple adenomasmay occur occasionally. Other rare causes include:••Ectopic aldosterone-producing tumorsFamilial idiopathic hyperaldosteronism - due to germline mutations of KCNJ5 (encodes apotassium channel)

questions.question: What is the underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome?
questions.explanation: The underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome is adrenal adenoma.Hyperaldosteronism may be primary or secondary.Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultantsuppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. It presentswith the following features:•Hypertension (most common)• Hypokalemia• Metabolic alkalosisPolyuria (due to ANP)• Polydipsia (due to polyuria)• Muscle weaknessIt is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity(PAC / PRA).When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Connsyndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal ofadenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmicinclusions called spironolactone bodies.1173Spironolactone bodiesSpironolactone bodiesEosinophiliccytoplasmicinclusionsIn secondary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone release occurs in response to the activation of therenin-angiotensin system (RAAS).

questions.question: Patients with which of the following conditions are not at risk of developing adrenocorticalcarcinoma?
questions.explanation: MEN2B syndrome is associated with pheochromocytoma and medullary carcinoma of thyroid,not adrenocortical carcinoma.Adrenocortical carcinoma is associated with the following hereditary cancer syndromes:• Li-Fraumeni syndrome - due to germline TP53 mutations• Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome a disorder of epigenetic imprinting-• MEN1 syndrome - due to mutations of MEN1 gene1174

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy is brought for the evaluation of recurrent seizures over the last 3 months.Past history is significant for chronic oral candidiasis for 2 years. On examination, nail1166dystrophy is noted. Further investigation reveals serum calcium of 6.9 mg/dl and prolongedQT interval. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of autoimmune polyendocrinopathy (APS) type 1. It is alsocalled APECED (autoimmune polyendocrinopathy, candidiasis, and ectodermal dystrophy).It is caused by mutations in the autoimmune regulator (AIRE) gene. This gene usually increasestolerance of central T-cells to peripheral tissue antigens. When this function is lost, the T-cellsbecome more prone to mount immune reactions against tissue antigens, promotingautoimmunity. These patients develop autoantibodies against IL-17 and IL-22, which are crucialfor defense against fungal infections.•It presents in childhood with the following features:Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis• Ectodermal dystrophy (abnormalities of the skin, dental enamel, and nails)• Organ-specific autoimmune disorders such as -• Autoimmune adrenalitis• Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism•Idiopathic hypogonadism• Pernicious anemiaAutoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (APS) type 2 usually presents in early adulthood as acombination of the following:• Adrenal insufficiency• Autoimmune thyroiditis or type 1 diabetes.

questions.question: Which of the following is most commonly involved in Wermer syndrome?
questions.explanation: Primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common manifestation of Wermer's syndrome orMEN-1 syndrome.MEN1 syndrome is due to germline mutations in the MEN1 tumor-suppressor gene, whichencodes a protein called menin. The most commonly secreted products are pancreaticpolypeptides.

questions.question: Which of the following is an indicator of malignant transformation in a patient withpheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation: The definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on thepresence of metastases to regional lymph nodes as well as distant sites like liver, lung, and bone.Capsular and vascular invasion may be encountered even in benign lesions. Malignantpheochromocytomas are histologically and biochemically the same as benign ones. Hence, typicalhistological criteria like cellular atypia, mitotic spindles, and vascular invasion are insufficient toconfirm malignancy in pheochromocytomas.

questions.question: A pathologist is studying the following slide from the biopsy of a patient with an abdominalmass. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given histopathology slide shows nests of cells arranged in an organoid pattern, withfibrovascular septae, and finely granular cytoplasm. This is called the zellballen pattern. It istypically seen in paragangliomas and pheochromocytomas.Paragangliomas are benign neuroendocrine tumors arising from paraganglia in the neck orabdomen. They are composed of chief and sustentacular cells arranged in an organoid pattern.1176Zellballen Pattern -Pheochromocytoma and ParagangliomaZellballen Pattern -Pheochromocytoma and ParagangliomaFibrovascularseptaeFinely granularcytoplasmNests of cells

questions.question: A 38-year-old woman was being evaluated for persistent hypertension. Workup revealed atumor located near the bifurcation of the aorta. Surgical excision was done and HPEexamination revealed a zellballen pattern of cells. Where did this tumor likely originate from?
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of a paraganglioma (ectopic pheochromocytoma) located in theabdomen. They commonly arise from the organ of Zuckerkandl, located at the bifurcation of theaorta. It is part of the vertebral paraganglia (clusters of chromaffin cells along the autonomicnerve chains).Other sites of origin of paragangliomas include:•Urinary bladder - rarely• Carotid and aortic bodies•Ganglion nodosum of the vagus nerveJugulotympanic ganglia1177

questions.question: 1168What mutation is likely to be seen in patients with familial paraganglioma syndrome?
questions.explanation: Familial paraganglioma is most likely associated with mutations in the SDH (succinatedehydrogenase) gene.The SDH complex is involved in mitochondrial electron transport and oxygen sensing. It isbelieved that SDH mutations also lead to the upregulation of HIF-1α, which is a key oncogenicdriver in this type of tumor.

questions.question: A 21-year-old young man presents with a neck mass. Past history is significant for surgicalremoval of a pheochromocytoma 6 months ago. On examination, a marfanoid habitus isnoted along with the following finding. Which of the following should the patient be screenedfor?
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing mucosal neuromas are suggestive of MEN2B syndrome.This condition is associated with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases of multiple endocrineorgans. Tumors occur at a younger age than sporadic tumors, either synchronously (at the sametime) or metachronously (at different times).MEN2 syndrome occurs due to abnormal activation of the RET gene. Medullary carcinoma is seenin both MEN 2A and 2B syndromes. However, it tends to be more aggressive and metastasizesmore frequently in MEN2B syndrome.Note: RET gene is deactivated in Hirschsprung disease.

questions.question: What gene is mutated in polycythemia paraganglioma syndrome?
questions.explanation: Polycythemia paraganglioma syndrome occurs due to germline mutations in the EPAS1 gene. Thissyndrome presents with neuroendocrine tumors and early-onset polycythemia.RET gene mutation is seen in MEN2A and MEN2B syndromes.SDHD and SDHB mutations are seen in hereditary paraganglioma 1 and hereditaryparaganglioma 4 syndromes respectively.1178
